name: bug
sources: Killip, Margaret. The Folklore of the Isle of Man. London: B. T. Batsford, Ltd., 1975, 106.

Ross, Anne. “Lindow Man and the Celtic Tradition.” In The Lindow Man: The Body in the Bog, edited by I. M. Stead, J. B. Bourke, and Don Brothwell, 162–169. Ithaca, N.Y.: Cornell University Press, 1986.
Spence, Lewis. The Minor Traditions of British Mythology. New York: Benjamin Blom, Inc., 1972, 87.
Monaghan, Patricia. The Encyclopedia of Celtic Mythology and Folklore. Checkmark Books, 2008.
text: A particular syllable, 'bug', is commonly found in the names of many mischievous sprites in different Celtic countries, such as bug-a-boo, bugbear, bullbeggar, bogle, Bogie, Bogan, and boggart, to name a few. Some argue that this frequency suggests these creatures are minor deities, as 'boge' is a word with divine meaning in other Indo-European languages. However, some scholars completely reject this interpretation. Others have connected the word 'bug' with 'Bog', a location viewed as a threshold to the Otherworld. In the Isle of Man, a bug or buggane was said to haunt St. Trinian’s, a church rumored to have been erected by St. Ninian during the 12th century. The church remained unroofed as every time roofers attempted the task, the buggane destroyed their work. In a bid to undo the buggane’s magic, a tailor sewed the roof to the rafters but the buggane threw his own head at him, chasing him away. Though the buggane never reappeared, the roof was never completed.
